children.value: We‚Äôre excited to announce an ongoing effort to maintain official translations of the React documentation website into different languages. Thanks to the dedicated efforts of React community members from around the world, React is now being translated into
languages! You can find them on the new
In addition, the following three languages have completed translating most of the React Docs! üéâ
, and all the contributors to the Spanish translation for being the first to
translate the core pages of the docs!

React already has many meetups and conferences around the world, but many programmers don‚Äôt use English as their primary language. We‚Äôd love to support local communities who use React by making our documentation available in most popular languages.
In the past, React community members have created unofficial translations for
; by making an official channel for these translated docs we‚Äôre hoping to make them easier to find and help make sure that non-English-speaking users of React aren‚Äôt left behind.
If you would like to help out on a current translation, check out the
page and click on the ‚ÄúContribute‚Äù link for your language.
Can‚Äôt find your language? If you‚Äôd like to maintain your language‚Äôs translation fork, follow the instructions in the
! You may know me as the
. For the past few weeks, I‚Äôve been helping the React team coordinate their translation effort. Here‚Äôs how I did it.
Our original approach for translations was to use a SaaS platform that allows users to submit translations. There was already a

to integrate it and my original responsibility was to finish that integration. However, we had concerns about the feasibility of that integration and the current quality of translations on the platform. Our primary concern was ensuring that translations kept up to date with the main repo and didn‚Äôt become ‚Äústale‚Äù.
encouraged me to look for alternate solutions, and we stumbled across how
maintained its translations ‚Äî through different forks of the main repo on GitHub. In particular, the
used a bot to periodically check for changes in the English repo and submits pull requests whenever there is a change.
This approach appealed to us for several reasons:
It was less code integration to get off the ground.
It encouraged active maintainers for each repo to ensure quality.
Contributors already understand GitHub as a platform and are motivated to contribute directly to the React organization.

We started off with an initial trial period of three languages: Spanish, Japanese, and Simplified Chinese. This allowed us to work out any kinks in our process and make sure future translations are set up for success. I wanted to give the translation teams freedom to choose whatever tools they felt comfortable with. The only requirement is a
that outlines the order of importance for translating pages.
After the trial period, we were ready to accept more languages. I created
to automate the creation of the new language repo, and a site,
, to track progress on the different translations. We started
new translations on our first day alone!
Because of the automation, the rest of the maintenance went mostly smoothly. We eventually created a
to make it easier for translators to share information, and I released a guide solidifying the
. Allowing translators to talk with each other was a great boon ‚Äî for example, the Arabic, Persian, and Hebrew translations were able to talk to each other in order to get
The most challenging part was getting the bot to sync changes from the English version of the site. Initially we were using the
bot created by the Japanese Vue translation team, but we soon decided to build our own bot to suit our needs. In particular, the che-tsumi bot works by
new commits. This ended up causing a cavalade of new issues that were interconnected, especially when

In the end, we decided that instead of cherry picking each commit, it made more sense to merge all new commits and create a pull request around once a day. Conflicts are merged as-is and listed in the
, leaving a checklist for maintainers to fix.
was easy enough: it downloads the translated repo, adds the original as a remote, pulls from it, merges the conflicts, and creates a pull request.
The problem was finding a place for the bot to run. I‚Äôm a frontend developer for a reason ‚Äî Heroku and its ilk are alien to me and
frustrating. In fact, until this past Tuesday, I was running the script by hand on my local machine!
The biggest challenge was space. Each fork of the repo is around 100MB ‚Äî which takes minutes to clone on my local machine. We have
forks, and the free tiers of most deployment platforms I checked limited you to 512MB of storage.
After lots of notepad calculations, I found a solution: delete each repo once we‚Äôve finished the script and limit the concurrency of
scripts that run at once to be within the storage requirements. Luckily, Heroku dynos have a much faster Internet connection and are able to clone even the React repo quickly.
There were other smaller issues that I ran into. I tried using the
add-on so I didn‚Äôt have to write any actual
code, but it end up running too inconsistently, and I
had an existential meltdown on Twitter
when I couldn‚Äôt figure out how to send commits from the Heroku dyno. But in the end, this frontend engineer was able to get the bot working!

There are, as always, improvements I want to make to the bot. Right now it doesn‚Äôt check whether there is an outstanding pull request before pushing another one. It‚Äôs still hard to tell the exact change that happened in the original source, and it‚Äôs possible to miss out on a needed translation change. But I trust the maintainers we‚Äôve chosen to work through these issues, and the bot is
if anyone wants to help me make these improvements!
Finally, I would like to extend my gratitude to the following people and groups:
All the translation maintainers and contributors who are helping translate React to more than thirty languages.
for initiating the idea of having bot-managed translations, and especially
for helping us understand their approach and helping maintain the Japanese translation.
and thoughtful comments on the overall translation process, as well as for maintaining the Japanese translation.
for managing our previous translation process.
for giving me this opportunity and being a great mentor along the way.
